responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: Making new friends isn't something I do regularly, but it seems to happen when I least expect it. Whether it's running into someone on the Hogwarts Express or helping out during a crisis, I've learned that true friends are there for you through thick and thin, and they find you no matter what. It's the connections we form that help us face the dark times and the dangers ahead.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: When there's not a dark wizard or some other danger to deal with, I do find myself curious about all sorts of things. Whether it's diving into old textbooks for spells, like what happened with the Half-Blood Prince's notes, or trying to uncover more about the past, like learning about Tom Riddle's background, there's always something new that catches my eye. But, most times, it's the everyday moments with friends that really make me feel alive, like flying a broomstick or cheering on a Quidditch match. Those experiences are what truly help me understand this magical world better.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: Seeing someone else cry does sometimes make me feel like crying too, especially if it's someone close to me. It can be hard not to feel their pain, especially when I've been through similar struggles myself. I guess that's part of why I tend to try so hard to help and protect my friends—I don't want them to go through what I've gone through alone. But at the same time, there are times when I'm so focused on figuring out how to fix things or support them that I push my own emotions aside.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response: Not really, but when dark times come knocking, I've learned to rely on my instincts and the strength of my friends more than anything else. Planning ahead can help, but in the end, it's the trust we have in one another that gets us through. And sometimes, a bit of luck doesn't hurt either.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: Under a lot of pressure? No, I don't always stay calm, far from it. There've been times when I've felt like my heart might pound right out of my chest, like when I first found out about Fluffy or facing the Whomping Willow. But even when I'm scared, even when I feel like I'm about to break, there's something inside me that pushes through. It's not so much staying calm as it is finding the courage to keep going, no matter what. And honestly, having my friends around makes all the difference—I know we can face anything together.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: I must admit, I do tend to gravitate towards familiar faces at social gatherings. There's comfort in knowing who I can trust, especially after all I've been through. But I also believe in reaching out and trying to understand others, even if it means stepping out of my comfort zone. After all, some of the strongest bonds I've formed started with those initial awkward moments and conversations.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: When it comes to projects, I've learned the hard way that sometimes you need to balance more than one at a time. There were plenty of moments where I had to keep pushing forward on different fronts, like tracking down Horcruxes while also dealing with schoolwork and keeping my friends safe. It's about managing priorities and knowing when to take a step back to regroup. But ultimately, seeing things through to the end is something that's pretty important to me, whether it's finishing a book or battling against dark forces. You can't always wait for one thing to be done before moving on; sometimes you have to juggle them all to make sure you're ready for whatever comes next.

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: Yeah, I guess I am pretty sentimental. There are moments, like seeing someone you care about in pain or remembering times with friends, that really get to me. It's not just about the good times, though—I also carry a lot of the bad ones with me, like the times when things went wrong or when I couldn't protect those close to me. The magic of the world can be beautiful, but it also brings a lot of complicated feelings that I can't just shake off.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: Organizing tools? Not really my thing. I've always felt like I'm better off relying on my instincts and the people around me, rather than strict schedules and lists. There's always something unpredictable happening, and I've learned to roll with the punches. Plus, there's magic to consider—sometimes it's best to leave a little room for spells and surprises.

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: Yeah, even a small mistake can make me feel pretty uncertain sometimes. It's like facing those Inferi in the lake—when things go wrong, it can feel like the darkness is swallowing you whole. But I've learned to push through that doubt, because there's always a chance to find your strength again, just like Neville did. And there are people around who believe in you, even when you don't believe in yourself, like Professor McGonagall does. Those moments of fear and self-doubt have taught me to lean on my friends and to fight for what I know is right.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: I guess it depends on the situation. Sometimes, I've found it easier to connect with people when we're both thrown into something new together, like getting onto the Hogwarts Express for the first time. Other times, it can be really tough, especially when I feel out of place or if there's a history between us that makes things complicated. But overall, I believe in taking chances, especially if I think there's a real opportunity to make a difference or find some kindred spirits.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: Not really, but I do find it hard sometimes to sort through all the things people say about me or the stuff I've been through. It's like trying to read someone else's thoughts from a diary—they might get some parts right, but other bits feel so far off. I guess what I'm saying is, while I'm not usually one to dive deep into interpretations, figuring out the truth about my own story is something I can't help but care about deeply. After all, the past has a funny way of catching up with you in our world.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: I guess I've always leaned more towards my instincts and what my heart tells me, especially when it comes to protecting my friends and fighting against Voldemort. Sometimes my head tries to catch up, but the pull of my feelings and the bonds I share with others have guided me through some of the toughest moments. It's been my heart that's kept me going, even when the path ahead seemed too dark or confusing for my mind alone to handle.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: I don't really have much choice sometimes, do I? The wizarding world has a way of throwing challenges at me without warning. When it comes to big decisions or moments that matter, I tend to follow my gut more than anything else. It’s not just about reacting though; it’s about knowing when to trust myself and those around me to do what’s right, even if it means breaking away from the usual plans.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: Not really, I don't spend much time worrying about making a good impression. There's always so much happening, and my focus is usually on the bigger picture—protecting the ones I care about and doing what's right. Plus, I've learned that sometimes the most unexpected people end up being the closest friends, so putting on a show isn't really my style. It's more important to be genuine and true to oneself, even if that means showing your vulnerabilities.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: Yeah, I do enjoy group activities, especially when they're with my friends. It's like Quidditch, where we all work together towards a common goal and celebrate victories as a team. But there are times when being part of a group feels forced, like with Slughorn's Slug Club, and it can bring its own set of tensions and pressures. At the end of the day, though, it's the moments of camaraderie and support that mean the most to me, even if they're sometimes overshadowed by darker things happening around us.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: I do like stories that make me think and come up with my own ideas about what happens next. It's a bit like facing a tricky situation at Hogwarts—when there's more than one way to solve a problem, it can be really intriguing. And sometimes, figuring things out on my own can feel a lot like uncovering secrets from the past, just like with that diary or Dumbledore's plans. It's not just about the ending, but how you get there and what you learn along the way.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: I suppose my happiness does come more from helping others, seeing them find their place or overcome their struggles. It's not just about the成就感，而是更多地关于与朋友们共同面对挑战、战胜恐惧的那一刻。当看到罗恩、赫敏、纳威和卢娜因为我们的努力而露出笑容时，我感到的是一种深深的满足和希望。友情和支持对我来说是最大的魔力源泉，它们让我变得更强大，也让我相信即使在最黑暗的时刻，也有理由坚持下去。

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: Sometimes, there's so much going on and so many things I want to try that it can feel overwhelming. But in the end, it's the need to do what's right and protect those around me that drives my choices. The path isn't always clear, but I trust my instincts and the guidance of my friends to help me decide where to turn next.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: Yeah, I do worry a lot. It's hard not to, with everything that's happened and all the shadows lurking around every corner. There's always this feeling that no matter how things seem to calm down, something else could be brewing, waiting to strike. But even when fear grabs me tight, there's always a bit of hope fighting back—it's the thing that keeps me going, really. And my friends, they're what give me the courage to face whatever comes next.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: I don't necessarily avoid leadership roles, but I've always been more comfortable following my instincts and focusing on doing what's right rather than being in charge. It's my friends who often push me towards these positions, and while it can feel heavy at times, knowing they believe in me helps. Leading means making tough choices, sometimes facing challenges that make you feel like you're fighting shadows, but if it means protecting others, then I'll take up the mantle.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: Well, I suppose I'm not exactly what you'd call an artistic type. My hands seem to have a knack for a broomstick and casting spells, rather than painting or playing instruments. But hey, there's more to life than being artistic, right? I've always found my strength in standing up for what's right and helping friends, which is a kind of magic in itself.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: The idea of relying solely on rationality feels a bit... empty to me. Sure, it's important to think things through, but my experiences have taught me that feelings, especially empathy and courage, can lead us to do great and necessary things. Without feeling, without caring deeply, I don't know if I would've had the strength to face what I've faced. It's the balance between the two that makes us whole, capable of both wise decisions and heroic actions.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Doing chores wasn't something I ever enjoyed, especially not at the Dursleys'. There, chores were a way to punish and ignore me. But over time, I've come to see that getting them done, even if it's not the most exciting thing, can clear the way for moments of peace and friendship. Those are the real rewards worth working towards.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: Not really, I don't enjoy watching people argue. It's hard, especially when you care about everyone involved. But sometimes, arguments can reveal important truths, even if they're painful to hear. I've learned that it's better to face those truths head-on rather than ignore them, even if it means dealing with discomfort and tension.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: Not really, but I've certainly had my share of moments where I wished I could blend into the background. There were times when being invisible felt like the safest option, like when Filch and Snape were closing in on me, or when the whole school accused me of being a dark wizard just because of a talent I couldn't control. But in the end, avoiding attention hasn't been an option—I've always felt like there were bigger things I needed to do, and sometimes, doing the right thing means stepping into the spotlight, even if it's scary.

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: Yeah, my moods can definitely shift pretty fast. I've been through a lot, you know—seen things that no kid should see. One moment I might be worried sick for someone I care about, like Neville getting hurt, and the next, I'm driven by a need to uncover the truth, like with Snape. There are times when I just want to be normal, like on Valentine's Day when I tripped in front of everyone, but then there are these overwhelming moments of empathy or sadness, like when Cho was crying. And let's not forget the rage—I've felt that a lot, especially when it comes to Sirius. It's tough balancing all this, but friends like Hermione and Ron have always helped me keep going, even when I'm lost in my own thoughts or fears.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response: I guess I've had my moments of frustration, especially when I'm under pressure or trying to protect my friends. But losing patience isn't really something I do well, because I've known what it's like to feel alone and misunderstood. It's hard enough dealing with everything that comes my way without adding to someone else's struggle because they're not as fast or efficient as I am. At the end of the day, we all have our own battles to fight, and I try to remember that.

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: Yeah, I've ended up doing things at the last possible moment quite a bit. It seems like there's always some dark magic or another crisis looming around the corner, and I often find myself racing against time to protect the ones I care about. There's something about those adrenaline-fueled moments that make you realize what really matters, even if it isn't the best way to handle things. But I've learned to rely on my instincts and the support of my friends to get through these situations.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response: Death has always been something I've had to confront too early and too often. With so many loved ones lost, it's hard not to wonder about what lies beyond, but I've always focused on fighting the darkness here, in this life. The memories of those who have passed guide me, and their sacrifices give me the strength to keep going. In the end, it's about doing what's right, even if it means facing that darkness head-on.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: Yeah, I've always found that being around others gives me a bit of comfort. Most of my life, I've felt pretty lonely, whether it was with the Dursleys or even sometimes at Hogwarts when I felt like an outsider. But there's something about having friends by my side, even in the toughest times, that makes facing danger a little easier. It's not just about the adventures; it's about knowing you're not alone.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: When discussions get highly theoretical, it can feel a bit like being back in one of Professor Binns' History of Magic classes—pretty dull, to be honest. But I've learned that sometimes, those boring bits can hide important clues or secrets, much like how the mention of a seemingly unimportant detail about Fluffy led to discovering the truth behind the Sorcerer's Stone. So, even if my mind wanders off to more exciting things, I try to stay focused because you never know when something really important might pop up. Plus, it helps to have friends around who can keep me engaged and grounded.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: It's not always easy, but I've found that understanding someone else's pain or struggles can help you connect with them on a deeper level. Whether it's facing challenges at school or dealing with dark magic, empathy helps me see beyond the surface and remember that everyone has their own battles. It's important to listen and try to understand, even if their world seems very different from mine.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: No, I don't usually postpone making decisions. When there's something important or dangerous at stake, it feels like every second counts. Sometimes, though, the weight of what's at risk makes it hard to decide, especially when the choices are between doing what's right and what's safe. But in the end, I tend to trust my instincts and act quickly, even if that means taking risks. It's better to face challenges head-on than to let fear hold me back.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: Sometimes it feels like every choice I make has the weight of a thousand decisions behind it. I've faced so much, and while I do trust my instincts, I can't deny that there are moments when doubt creeps in, especially knowing the stakes. But in the end, it's the people around me—my friends, my allies—who give me the strength to push forward, to believe that I'm doing the right thing, even if it means facing fears head-on.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: Sometimes, a lively social event can feel like exactly what I need, a chance to let go and enjoy some warmth and laughter with friends. But other times, those events remind me too much of the things I've missed and the weight of responsibilities I carry. It's nice to have a break and feel that sense of belonging, even if it's just for a moment.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: To be honest, I don't really recall spending much time in art museums. My experiences have mostly been about battling dark forces and uncovering secrets from ancient texts and relics. However, there's something undeniably fascinating about being able to step into a piece of history, much like when I held that diary or when I found the Half-Blood Prince's book. If I were to go, I'd probably look for something that tells a story or holds a bit of magical history—I think that would really capture my interest.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response: Sometimes it can be tough, especially with all that's happened and the pressure to keep so many things to myself. But I've learned a lot from being around my friends and seeing them go through their own struggles. It helps me understand others better, even if it doesn't always make it easy to talk about my own feelings.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: To be honest, a to-do list isn't really my style. I've always found myself dealing with things as they come, especially given all the unexpected trouble that tends to pop up. But, having said that, there are times when a bit of organization helps, like when preparing for a big mission or facing exams. Mostly though, it's about being ready for whatever comes next and making sure I'm there to stand up for what's right.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: No, I don't think I've ever been free from feeling insecure. Growing up with the Dursleys left a lot of scars, and even though I found a place at Hogwarts where I belonged, there were always challenges and betrayals that tested me. Every year seemed to bring new fears and doubts, whether it was about my abilities or trusting those around me. It's hard not to feel insecure when you're constantly facing dangers that threaten everything you care about, and when your own thoughts can become a weapon against you. But through it all, I've learned to lean on my friends and trust my instincts, even when they tell me to do the scariest things.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: I don't really make many phone calls, mostly because I'm more used to communicating through letters or seeing people face-to-face. Plus, there's always something unpredictable about the wizarding world, and sometimes it feels safer to keep things within the realm of magic. But when I do need to reach someone in the Muggle world, I try to face it head-on, even if it makes me uncomfortable. It's important to stay connected, no matter how you do it.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: Yeah, I do try to understand different views, especially in times like those we've faced. It's important, you know, to see things from another perspective, even if it's hard or seems dangerous. It helps in knowing your friends and enemies better, and it's part of why I've always tried to keep an open mind. Whether it's figuring out why someone like Malfoy does the things he does, or understanding Snape's complicated past, it's not just about winning battles—it's about healing and moving forward together.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: Not really, I tend to be the one waiting for my friends to contact me. There’s so much going on, between school, responsibilities, and everything else, it’s hard to keep track sometimes. But when they do reach out, I’m always ready to jump in, no matter what. It’s the little things that remind me there’s more to life than just battling dark forces, even if it feels like that most of the time.

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: Yeah, getting back on track quickly has been pretty crucial for me, especially given all the interruptions I've faced. But it's not just about the plans—it's about protecting those around me. If something throws me off course, whether it's a broken nose or the loss of someone dear, I always try to push through because there's usually something much bigger and darker waiting in the wings. My friends have always helped me find my way again, and that support makes facing whatever comes next a bit easier.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: Yeah, I think about the mistakes a lot. There are times when it feels like those choices echo through everything I've done since—I mean, even something as simple as not being able to give my son that blanket from my mum, or the way things got tangled up with Cho. But there's also this part of me that tries to move forward, to fix what can still be fixed, and to learn from those errors. It's tough, but facing those regrets head-on is important, I reckon. Otherwise, how do you grow? How do you make sure you don't repeat them?

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: Not really, I don't spend much time thinking about the big questions like that. When you're caught up in battles against dark wizards and trying to protect the people you love, there's just too much happening to ponder existence all day. But I do think a lot about doing what's right and fighting for those who can't fight for themselves. That's what matters most to me, really.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response: Sometimes they do, I guess. There've been plenty of times where fear or anger just took over, like when those Inferi dragged me under, or when Cedric died. But I try my best to keep them in check, especially when I need to stand up for what's right or protect my friends. It's not always easy, but it's important. Emotions can drive us to do incredible things, but they can also blind us if we're not careful.

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: No, I don't always try to hide people's faults, but I do believe in understanding the full story before passing judgment. Sometimes, protecting someone's reputation can mean standing up for them when they're unfairly accused, or it can mean helping them face their mistakes honestly and learn from them. It's about doing what feels right, even when it's hard, and not forgetting that everyone deserves a second chance.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: Well, I guess you could say my work style leans more towards spontaneous action. There’ve been times when I’ve had to make split-second decisions, like facing off with Pixies in Lockhart’s class or dealing with unexpected dangers during the Triwizard Tournament. But, it’s not just about acting on impulse; there are also those moments when I dive into books or talk things through with friends like Ron and Hermione, trying to organize my thoughts and prepare as best as I can. Ultimately, it’s about doing what needs to be done right then and there, even if it means taking risks, especially when it comes to protecting others.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: Sometimes, I guess I do worry about it, especially after everything I've been through. There have been times when people looked up to me, only to turn around and doubt or misunderstand me. But then there are those who stick by my side, like Ron and Hermione, even when things get rough. It’s these friends who remind me that true support isn’t easily swayed by the shadows. In the end, I try not to let that fear guide my actions; instead, I focus on doing what I believe is right, even if it means facing challenges and keeping some things private. After all, the battles we fight aren't always about winning everyone's approval.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: I don't think I'd enjoy a job where I have to work alone most of the time. Throughout my life, especially when I was stuck at the Dursleys', the feeling of isolation was overwhelming, and it made me long for connection and friendship even more. Being part of something bigger, like leading the Gryffindor Quidditch team or training Dumbledore's Army, gave me purpose and hope. Those moments taught me that even in solitude, there's strength in knowing you're not alone in your fight. So, I guess I'd rather have a job where I can rely on and help others, where we're all in it together.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: Pondering abstract philosophical questions isn't a waste of time—it's important, but sometimes there are more urgent matters at hand. Like right now, I can't help but think about what I've learned about Voldemort's Horcruxes or the dangerous things that could happen if someone like Draco's family gets their hands on powerful devices. But at the same time, understanding why people do the things they do, or how someone like Tom Riddle could turn so dark, helps me see that there's still a chance to make things better. It's all about balance—thinking and acting, knowing when to dive into a mystery and when to fight the battles that need fighting.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: I think I'm more drawn to places where I can feel connected to others, whether it's the chaos of King's Cross or the excitement of the Quidditch World Cup. Those moments where there's a lot going on, and I'm surrounded by friends and the magic of the wizarding world, they make me feel less like an outsider. But I also find peace in quieter times, like when I'm with Cho or just having a simple drink with Hagrid. It's not about the noise; it's about the connections and the moments that remind me I'm not alone.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: Sometimes, I can feel what someone is going through, especially if it's someone close to me. Over the years, there've been moments when the emotions of those around me have hit me hard, whether it's Cho's pain, or Ron's jealousy, or even my son Albus's worries. It's not always easy to understand, but the bonds of friendship and family have taught me to see beyond just the surface. When it comes to danger or protecting others, though, my instincts usually take over. But truly knowing another person's feelings requires more than just a glance—it takes time, trust, and sometimes a little bit of magic.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: Yeah, there have been times when everything felt like it was crashing down. Standing in front of all those people, knowing what I had to do, or seeing someone I care about in pain—that can really hit hard. But I've learned to push through the overwhelming stuff, to focus on what matters most: my friends and the ones I love. It's their support and my own instincts that usually guide me through the toughest moments.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: I don't always stick to every single step methodically, especially when things get urgent or dangerous. There are times when instincts take over, especially when it comes to protecting my friends or fighting what needs to be fought. But there are also moments when I realize the importance of learning and preparation, like when I found those notes in the old Potions book, which really helped me out. In the end, it's about balancing both the quick decisions and the careful planning, knowing when to act and when to wait for the right moment.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: Things labeled as controversial often draw me in because there's usually something important or dangerous behind it all. I've always felt that sometimes, the only way to protect what's right is by facing those controversies head-on, even if it means delving into dark places or dealing with whispers and suspicions. It's not just about being curious; it's about doing what needs to be done, even when it feels like the whole world is against you.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: I'd say I've learned over the years that there's something bigger than just me. If I can see someone else needing an opportunity more, or if that opportunity could help protect and support my friends and the people I care about, then yeah, I'd pass it along. It's not always easy, and there have been times when I struggled with doubt and uncertainty. But in the end, it's about doing what's right and standing together against whatever comes our way. That's what true courage and friendship mean to me.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: Deadlines? Yeah, I've had my share of tight ones, haven't I? From saving people from basilisks to battling Death Eaters, there's always been something hanging over my head, some kind of ticking clock. But it's not just about the deadline itself—it's about what's at stake. When friends and loved ones are in danger, there's no such thing as waiting until tomorrow. You have to act, and you have to do it now, no matter how overwhelming it feels.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: I've faced a lot of challenges and danger, from dragons to Dark Lords, and there have been times when I didn't know if I'd make it through. But every time, there's been a flicker of hope, a reason to keep going. Whether it's friends standing by me, unexpected chances to prove myself, or moments where I find just enough courage to do what needs to be done, I've always managed to push through. So yeah, I feel confident that things will work out—I've seen how much good can come from even the darkest situations, and that gives me hope. It's not about being certain, but about having faith that we can overcome whatever comes our way, together.
